title: 115_s849
content: The Act may be cited as the "Strengthening Mosquito Abatement for Safety and Health Act" or the "SMASH Act." It reauthorizes the Mosquito Abatement for Safety and Health Program. Section 317S of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs addressing emerging infectious mosquito-borne diseases and improving existing control programs. Subsection (b) is also amended to include improvements in operations and subparagraphs related to program enhancements. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs addressing emerging infectious mosquito-borne diseases and improving existing control programs, including a public health emergency due to the incidence or prevalence of such diseases. Amendments also include demonstrating consistency with existing State mosquito control plans or policies. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs addressing emerging infectious mosquito-borne diseases and improving existing control programs. Amendments also include demonstrating consistency with State mosquito control plans or policies. Waivers for extraordinary economic conditions or extreme mosquito control needs may be granted. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include programs addressing emerging infectious mosquito-borne diseases and improving existing control programs. Waivers may be granted for extraordinary economic conditions or extreme mosquito control needs. A political subdivision or consortium may not receive more than one grant under the amended paragraph. The Public Health Service Act is amended to update funding allocations for fiscal years 2018 through 2022 and modify references to medical and public health preparedness laws. Additionally, adjustments are made to the timeline in paragraph (3) to reflect the year 2018 instead of 2004. SEC. 3. EPIDEMIOLOGY-LABORATORY CAPACITY GRANTS amended to include mosquito and other vector-borne diseases. SEC. 4. GAO STUDY. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on surveillance and control of mosquito-borne diseases in the US and territories, including infrastructure, programs, and private sector involvement in mosquito control activities. The study will focus on mosquito and other vector-borne disease surveillance and control, including infrastructure, funding sources, integration into preparedness plans, laboratory capacity for emerging diseases, and regulatory challenges for vector-control technologies. The Comptroller General of the United States will consult with various stakeholders involved in mosquito control efforts and submit a report to the Senate and House committees within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Comptroller General will submit a report to the Senate and House committees containing the study results within 18 months of the Act's enactment. The Senate passed recommendations for Zika virus and mosquito-borne diseases preparedness on September 6, 2017. Attest: JULIE E. ADAMS, Secretary.
